title: 3 U.S. Marijuana Stocks to Buy and 1 to Sell, According to Analysts
text:
Text size

Wall Street is warming up to a few marijuana firms that—because pot is banned under federal law—can’t even list on the New York Stock Exchange or Nasdaq.

Even though many expect the U.S. marijuana market to be the biggest in the world, growers based here like Green Thumb Industries, Cresco Labs, and Curaleaf Holdings trade at a discount to their Canadian peers.

A team of analysts at Cowen thinks that may soon change. They joined a growing contingent who are bullish on select U.S. pot companies known as multistate operators, or MSOs.

“With the U.S. operators penalized from a tax perspective, handcuffed in terms of true scientific research and restricted in terms of geographic optionality outside of the U.S., the operating paradigm is quite nuanced, relative to Canadian cannabis,” they wrote.

Still, they believe these companies have an easier time developing their brands due to regulatory nuances that let them operate in a way not much different from traditional packaged-goods companies. It is a business model “that relies more on high-margin finished goods, as opposed to specialty retail,” the analysts wrote.

The team initiated coverage on five growers—three at Buy, one to Hold, and one to Sell. Here’s what they had to say about each.

Green Thumb Industries (ticker: GTBIF) won an Outperform rating with a price target of $18.50. “GTI is our highest conviction Outperform among all the U.S. MSOs now under our coverage,” the analysts wrote.

“While several of GTI’s peers have been keenly focused on rapidly expanding their retail footprints to build dominant retail brands, GTI has taken a slower, but we think more thoughtful approach, by balancing revenue mix between wholesale and retail,” they said.

The analysts also cited the company’s brand portfolio, presence in high-growth markets, and strong management team.

The company reported adjusted operated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of $4.7 million in the first half of 2019. The profit amounts to 6.4% of sales. “While many peers discuss the margin benefits associated with the effects of scaling operations, GTI is one of the few MSOs on track to post near-term results that support such assertions,” the report said.

Cresco Labs (CRLBF) also achieved an Outperform rating, with a $14 price target.

Cresco has made branded products and wholesale distribution its priorities, they noted. Rather than expanding to as many states as possible, Cresco has been more focused on building depth in the states where it does operate.

“[Cresco] is more focused on establishing a robust wholesale business by curating a portfolio of brands that can fully penetrate a market,” they wrote.

Curaleaf Holdings (CURLF), with a price target of $10.50, was the third company rated at Outperform.

“Curaleaf has positioned itself as one of the largest MSOs in the market, leading our coverage universe in terms of organic revenue generation, as well as pro forma revenues,” they wrote.

The company has about $2 billion in pending acquisitions, so mergers and acquisitions could be a catalyst for future gains, the analysts said. They noted, though, that the transactions are subject to antitrust review.

The company’s revenue base—and ability to generate Ebitda in the latest quarter—make it appealing in terms of scale and profitability, the report said.

MedMen (MMNFF), on the other hand, received an Underperform rating, with a $1.50 price target.

The company has focused on retail sales. “While in isolation, this is a durable business model, in the nascent cannabis industry, we favor higher margin mix from wholesale,” the analysts said.

The report said that while MedMen is the leader in the California market, reflecting what the analysts called an “attractive retail concept,” the company’s reliance on retail sales, its spending levels, and management turnover are concerns.

Acreage Holdings (ACRGF) came in at Market Perform, with a $9 price target.

Acreage has a presence in 19 states, not counting a pending acquisition in Nevada, giving it the broadest position in the U.S. pot market. Still, the Cowen team said there is little in the works that could send the stock higher.

The company has a deal to be acquired by Canadian firm Canopy Growth (CGC), but that would only be triggered if the U.S. legalizes marijuana.

“We value ACRG on a stand-alone basis without line of sight to completion of the [Canopy Growth] WEED deal,” they wrote. “Given its low margin profile and dependency on M&A, we do not see much multiple upside beyond peer averages, which caps valuation upside.”
